STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 27, 2023
Linda Needham
Lenawee County DHHS
1040 S. Winter St.,
Adrian, MI, 49221-3876
RE: License#: CP460201242
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/26/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP460201242
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Linda Needham
Name of Agency: Lenawee County DHHS
Agency Address: 1040 S. Winter St.
Adrian, MI 49221-3876

Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health
code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All the following
apply…
Two of six foster care files did not have documentation of current immunizations.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs(a-j)
One of six foster care files did not have documentation (DHHS-69) completed as
required for two changes in placement.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:

(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of two closed foster care files did not have documentation (DHHS-69)
completed as required when a case was no longer serviced by the agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/16/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/9/22. Previously cited as FOM 722-08E
FC/JJ action summary.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent
living with a copy of the agency’s policies and
procedures required by this rule.
One of two independent living (IL) case files did not have documentation the
youth was provided with copies of IL policy and procedure.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of two IL files did not have documentation the youth was provided with a
copy of the IL program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision: (b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the
youth is complying with the terms of the agreement
required by R 400.12510, continues to reside in a safe
and acceptable environment, and is managing
expenditures.
One of two IL files did not have a monthly budget completed for August 2023.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision: (c) Provide the youth with a telephone

number to contact the agency on a 24-hour, 7-days-a-
week basis.
One of two IL files did not have documentation the youth was provided with a
phone number to contact the agency on a 24/7 basis.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care
(2) For a youth who become 18 years of age while in
the program or who enters independent living after the
age of 18, the agency shall provide information on how
to access needed medical, dental, and mental health
services and actively, and on an ongoing basis,
encourage participation in needed medical, dental, and
mental health services.
One of two IL files did not have documentation the youth was provided with
information about how to access medical, dental, and mental health services.
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
One of six foster care files did not have an FTM completed within 30 days prior to
the March 2023 USP.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Three of six foster care files did not have medical passports updated on a
quarterly basis.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Policy office clarified that medical passports must be updated quarterly, even
if a foster parent or parent signature is not required at that time. Medical

passports must be updated and uploaded into MiSACWIS to verify the date it
was updated.
• Special evaluations must have each interview document in the description of
findings on the special evaluation report. A brief summary of the interview is
acceptable.
• Independent Living agreement (contract) must be updated and reviewed with
youth quarterly. Youth must sign and date the agreement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
11/16/22 interim review, CAP approved 12/9/22. During the 2022 interim review
the agency had six violations regarding home visits, staff training, treatment plan
signatures, case contact entry, family team meetings, and action summaries. The
agency reported successful implementation of their CAP during the past year.
They have shown significant improvement in most areas of the CAP. However,
there was one repeat violation regarding documentation required for closed cases.
The agency will address this in their new CAP along with the additional violations
from this review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. The Chief
Administrator (CA) indicated the agency has worked hard to come into compliance
with CAP items from the 2022 review. This was achieved through increased
oversight and implementation of tools to support consistency among staff. The CA
identified some ongoing challenges throughout the year, including staffing
changes, difficulties with utilizing a new system (CWLM), and difficulty finding
placement for high needs youth. Identifying placements for certain youth has been
a state-wide issue.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.

Staff Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. Two licensing staff were interviewed and
shared several concerns about implementing the new licensing rules, and
difficulties utilizing CWLM for reports and contacts. The staff reported feeling
supported by their supervisor as they learn the new rules and how to regulate
them, as well as handle CWLM issues with the helpdesk. A foster care case
manager was interviewed and stated she currently has the best supervisor she
has ever had. Her supervisor is supportive, knowledgeable, helpful, and always
available. The worker noted the job can be very difficult, but she has the right
amount of support. None of the staff had any concerns or suggestions for
improvement within the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the county building in Adrian. The office has
adequate space for staff and clients to meet. There is sufficient storage space for
confidential information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert regarding a pool that did not meet licensing rules. The
safety alert was resolved when the pool was drained, and the foster parent agreed
it will not be filled again until the agency has verified compliant safety barriers are in
place.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ ____________September 26, 2023_____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 27, 2023

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
